chapter.title: Books
chapter.para: The simplest kind of publication is undoubtedly the standard book. If everyone simply published books, bibliography would be easy! A book generally has one or more authors, a title, a place and time of publication and an extent in number of pages.
Place of publication is broken down into the name of the city that is the chief domicile of the publishing house and the name of the publishing house itself.

ul.li: Diamond, Jared. Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies. New York: W. W. Norton and Company, 1997.
Bird, Kai, and Martin J. Sherwin. American Prometheus: The Triumph and Tragedy of J. Robert Oppenheimer. New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2005.

chapter.para: In connection with place and time of publication, one generally also notes information regarding the edition, but since the Tamboti simplfied input forms are primarily meant to be used when catalgouging first editions of Cluster publications, input options for edition are not shown, since one generally does not register the circumstance that a publication is the first edition. Edition information can be found on the Origin Info tab.
Extent in number of pages is generally not shown in the bibliographical notice for a book.

A book may also have an editor, a translator and an illustrator, and so on, but this is not taken into account in the Basic Input Forms. Such "role terms" are available, along with more than 200 other terms, on the Name Info tab.
